journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Stability region analysis of the parasitic loop of the semi-strapdown homing seeker

article-meta.aff: 1Key Laboratory of Dynamics and Control of Flight Vehicle, Ministry of Education, School of Aerospace Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing, China
2China Aerospace Science & Industry Corp, Beijing, China

author-notes.corresp: *Key Laboratory of Dynamics and Control of Flight Vehicle, Ministry of Education, School of Aerospace Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing, China email: sjm318@bit.edu.cn

abstract.p: The stability of the parasitic loop induced by the disturbance rejection effect (DRE) of a semi-strapdown homing seeker (SSHS) is analysed in this paper. First, the seeker’s tracking controller is designed so as to have a simple structure and then the explicit relationships between the control parameters and the desired performance index is presented. Mathematical models of the DRE of the SSHS and the parasitic loop are then proposed. The approximate maximum magnitude of the seeker’s DRE as a function of the friction coefficient and the counter electromotive force coefficient is also given. Routh’s criterion is used to obtain the approximate stability region of the parasitic loop. The necessary and sufficient conditions which ensure the stability of the parasitic loop are directly related to the seeker’s control parameters. This approach provides direct theoretical support for the design of a seeker’s control system. Simulations are performed to verify the validity of the stability analysis performed on the parasitic loop.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: The homing seekers installed on missiles can be divided into three types based on the manner of their installation.

list-item.p: A platform-stabilized seeker: the detector is fixed on the base of the inertial platform as are the inertial sensors.
A strapdown homing seeker: the detector and the inertial sensors are all directly fixed onto the body of the missile.
A semi-strapdown homing seeker (SSHS): the detector is fixed onto the gimbal platform but the inertial sensors are removed from the gimbal platform and fixed onto the body of the missile.

sec.p: The mechanical structure of a SSHS is relatively simple compared with the platform-stabilized seeker and it is therefore much lighter, smaller in volume, and cheaper to produce. The instantaneous field of view of the SSHS detector is smaller than that of a strapdown seeker and the SSHS can track targets with a larger manoeuvring overload. Thus, there is considerable interest in using a SSHS in weapon systems. However, there is no mechanism currently available that allows the SSHS system to isolate the attitude manoeuvring process of the missile’s body, and thus the its attitude disturbances can easily become coupled into the seeker’s optical axis, which presents a significant challenge for the guidance system design of SSHSs.

There is an extensive literature on SSHS systems. Waldmann [1] built a model of the dynamics of a two-degree-of-freedom (2-DOF) SSHS and used the extended Kalman filter approach to estimate the angular rate of the gimbal. An analysis based on Monte Carlo simulations was made which demonstrated the application of the SSHS in the guidance system of a missile. Kennedy and Kennedy [2] analysed the way in which disturbances were coupled into the line-of-sight (LOS) tracking vector for the platform-stabilized seeker and the SSHS. This work highlighted that more error sources were created in the SSHS system. Zhou [3] presented a complete dynamics model of a pitch–yaw SSHS which was used as the basis of a compensation algorithm and a robust controller. The majority of the existing literature is focused on the modelling of the dynamics and design of a control system and to date no mathematical model of the disturbance rejection effect (DRE) of a SSHS has been proposed. The concept of the DRE for the SSHS was first proposed by Rudin [4]. It was clearly demonstrated in reference [4] that it was necessary to design a matching filter to improve the seeker’s DRE when the dynamic characteristics of the gimbal angular sensor and the rate gyro were significantly different. Simulations for the missile body attitude created by various maneuvering procedures were presented in reference [4] to demonstrate the seeker’s DRE. However, the concept of a parasitic loop in the SSHS was not discussed in that work. In Xiao et al. [5], the DRE of the roll–pitch SSHS was simulated after the tracking controller of the SSHS had been designed.

To date, there does not appear to be any reports in the literature that discuss the concept of a parasitic loop induced by the DRE of a SSHS. The concept a parasitic loop for a platform-stabilized radar seeker with a radome slope error was posed by Nesline and Zarchan [6] and Carnell and East [7]. The stability region of the parasitic loop induced by the radome slope error was presented, and also the effect of the radome slope error on the miss distance was analysed in these papers.

This paper finds that a parasitic loop does exist in the SSHS system. This loop can become unstable if the parameters of the seeker’s tracking controllers are selected inappropriately, and furthermore it may make the whole guidance loop unstable. Thus, the stability of the parasitic loop is a very important problem in the SSHS systems that will be discussed in this paper.

This paper is organized as follows. First, the tracking control system of the SSHS is designed. Then, a mathematical model of the seeker’s DRE and the parasitic loop of the SSHS are proposed. By analysing the stability of the parasitic loop induced by the seeker’s DRE, the stability regions of the main controller variables of the seeker’s control system are obtained under various disturbances, such as friction coefficient, counter electromotive force (EMF) coefficient, and a dynamic mismatch between the sensors. Simulations are performed to verify the correctness of the stability analysis. Finally, a simulation is performed in which all three disturbance factors are simultaneously considered.

sec.title: 2 Mathematical Modelling of the Parasitic Loop
2.1 Dynamics equation of the 2-DOF SSHS
sec.p: Assuming the rotational inertia of the inner gimbal of the SSHS with the electrooptical payload in the inner gimbal coordinate frame is J¯inin and the rotational inertia of the outer gimbal in the outer gimbal coordinate frame is J¯oo
Then, the rotational inertia of the inner gimbal in the outer gimbal coordinate frame is J¯oin and its differential is J¯·oin, which can be written as
where T¯in→o is the transformation matrix from the inner gimbal coordinate frame to the outer gimbal coordinate frame, which can be written as

Assuming that the projection of the rotational angular rate of the missile’s body relative to the inertial coordinate frame in the missile body coordinate frame is ωbb/i=[ωxωyωz]T. Then, the projection of the rotational angular rate of the missile’s body relative to the inertial coordinate frame in the outer gimbal coordinate frame is ωob/i=[abc]T=[ωxcosλy−ωzsinλyωyωxsinλy+ωzcosλy]T, and its differential is ω·ob/i=[a·b·c·]T.

The projection of the rotational angular rate of the inner gimbal relative to the outer gimbal coordinate frame in the outer gimbal coordinate frame is ωoin/o=[00λ·z]T. The projection of the rotational angular rate of the outer gimbal relative to the missile body coordinate frame in the outer gimbal coordinate frame is ωoo/b=[0λ·y0]T. Then, the projection of the rotational angular rate of the inner gimbal relative to the inertial coordinate frame in the outer gimbal coordinate frame is ωoin/i=[ab+λ·yc+λ·z]T, and the projection of the rotational angular rate of the outer gimbal relative to the inertial coordinate frame in the outer gimbal coordinate frame is ωoo/i=[ab+λ·yc]T.

According to the Euler dynamics theory and momentum moment theorem [8], the momentum moment of the inner gimbal can be written as Hoin=J¯oinωoin/i and the momentum moment of the outer gimbal can be written as Ho=J¯ooωoo/i+J¯oinωoin/i.
Substituting the corresponding variables into the expressions for Hoin and Ho, the mathematical dynamic model of the 2-DOF SSHS can be obtained as follows [9]
where Kviz and Kviy are friction coefficients, Ksiz and Ksiy are linear restoring torque coefficients, and Tz and Ty are control torques.

sec.title: 2.2. Tracking control system design for a SSHS
sec.p: In this paper, the stability of the parasitic loop is only discussed for a one-degree-of-freedom SSHS. The dynamics equation of the SSHS can be simplified to
where J=Izin, Kvi=Kviz, Ksi=Ksiz.
The definitions of the angles in the SSHS are shown in Fig. 1. The meaning of all the variables and the particular values used in all simulations are listed in the Appendix.

caption.p: Definitions of the angles in the SSHS

sec.p: The linear restoring torque is ignored here since it has only a very small influence on the DRE of the SSHS. A schematic diagram of the angular tracking control system for the SSHS is shown in Fig. 2, where Gc1(s)=Kp(Tps+1)/(Tps) and Gc2(s)=Kv(Tvs+1)/(Tvs) are the controllers for the angular tracking loop (outer control loop) and the angular rate tracking loop (inner control loop) respectively under proportional–integral control. With LKvi being omitted, the transfer function of the controlled plant (shown in the dashed block in Fig. 2) can be approximately expressed as

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the seeker’s tracking control system

sec.p: where
Since the term Te is very small, Gm(s) can be simplified to Gm(s)=K/(Tms+1), then the transfer function of the angular rate tracking loop can be obtained as
The expected closed-loop transfer function for the seeker’s angular rate tracking loop is set as Gexpect(s)=1/(Tas+1) for convenience, then the controller parameters of Gc2(s) are designed as

Using the frequency analysis and design method approaches found in automatic control theory [10], the parameters of Gc1(s) can be designed as Kp=wc and Tp=tan(γ)/wc, where, wc and γ are the expected phase-crossover frequency and phase-margin of the seeker’s angular tracking loop, respectively. For simplicity, wc and γ are set to wc=20rad/s and γ=80∘, respectively, and then Tp=0.2836 and Kp=20 for the SSHS given in the Appendix. In this way, the inertial time-constant of the SSHS tracking system is almost constant, at a value of T=0.05s. The response speed of the seeker’s angular tracking loop can be adjusted to satisfy the requirements of a realistic SSHS system by altering the value of wc, which considerably simplifies the stability analysis of the parasitic loop.

sec.title: 2.3 Mathematic model of the DRE and parasitic loop
sec.p: The mathematical model of a guided missile with a SSHS after the seeker’s tracking controllers have been designed is shown in Fig. 3. The dynamics of the gimbal angular sensor and rate gyro are also included in Fig. 3. The simplified mathematical models of the autopilot and navigation noise filter presented in references [11] and [12] are adopted in this paper to facilitate the stability analysis.

caption.p: Mathematical model of the SSHS guided missile system

sec.p: The section in the dashed block in Fig. 3 can be equivalently transformed to Gd(s) and GR(s), respectively, as shown in Fig. 4, where Gd(s) is the model of the seeker’s tracking control system; it is the transfer function from qz to ϑ·d and represents the tracking ability of the seeker’s optical axis. GR(s) is the model of the DRE of the SSHS; it is the transfer function from ϑ· to ϑ·d and it represents the incorrect angular rate caused by an attitude disturbance applied to the missile’s body. The section in the dashed block in Fig. 4 is the parasitic loop induced by the DRE of the SSHS.

caption.p: Simplified model of the SSHS guided missile system

sec.p: It can be seen from Figs 3 and 4 that since the response speed of the seeker’s servo system is limited then the angular rate of the missile’s body ϑ· will be transferred to the LOS rate of the optical axis by the disturbance factors including such terms as the friction torque, counter EMF coefficient, and dynamic mismatches between the sensors. Then, the LOS rate caused by the missile body’s attitude disturbance will be added to the actual LOS rate; that is, an incorrect LOS rate signal will be produced by the SSHS. The error LOS rate is used by the proportional-navigation control law to create an autopilot command which makes the missile perform incorrect manoeuvres. This incorrect attitude manoeuvre is fed back through the friction coefficient, counter EMF coefficient, and dynamic mismatches between the sensors, and then another erroneous LOS rate signal is produced and enacted, and so on. The parasitic loop is locally a positive feedback system as shown in Fig. 4. The influence of the friction coefficient, the counter EMF coefficient, and dynamic mismatches between the sensors on the stability of the parasitic loop will be studied in the following sections.

sec.title: 3 Influence of Friction Coefficient on the Stability of the Parasitic Loop
3.1 Stability analysis of the parasitic loop based on the whole model of the DRE
sec.p: The part in the dashed block in Fig. 3 is shown as Fig. 5 with only the friction coefficient being considered as a disturbance factor. Then, the transfer function of the DRE can be obtained as

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the whole DRE model

sec.p: With some small terms being omitted, the denominator of the closed-loop transfer function of the parasitic loop in the dashed block in Fig. 4 can be expressed as
where
and
Applying Routh’s criterion, the necessary and sufficient condition which ensures the stability of the parasitic loop can be approximately obtained as

sec.title: 3.2 Stability analysis of parasitic loop based on the simplified DRE model
sec.p: Examining equation (3), it becomes clear that the necessary and sufficient condition which ensures the stability of the parasitic loop can be approximately considered to be solely related to the controller parameters of Gc2(s) and therefore has no significant relationship with Gc1(s). Furthermore, it is also shown in Fig. 3 that attitude manoeuvring of the missile’s body is introduced into the seeker’s tracking system directly through the seeker’s inner angular rate tracking loop. Therefore, in order to reduce system complexity and to facilitate the stability analysis, the effect of the seeker’s outer angular tracking loop is ignored; in that case the simplified DRE model can be schematically represented as in Fig. 6. Then, it can be written that

caption.p: Schematic representation of the simplified DRE model

sec.p: Using equation (4) it can be calculated that the magnitude of GR(s) reaches its maximum at the frequency w=Kvi/(JTa) and its maximum magnitude (MM) is 20lg[TaKvi/(J+TaKvi)]. The relationship between the friction coefficient and the MM of the DRE is shown in Fig. 7, where P=J/Ta. It can be seen from Fig. 7 that the greater the friction coefficient then the greater the MM of the DRE; the smaller the inertial moment J or the greater the Ta then the greater the MM of the DRE. A larger MM will destabilize the parasitic loop.

caption.p: MM for the DRE as a function of the friction coefficient

sec.p: Similarly, the condition which ensures the stability of the parasitic loop can be approximately obtained for the closed-loop transfer function of the parasitic loop in the dashed block in Fig. 4; it turns out to be the same as in equation (3).

Therefore, only the transfer function of the simplified DRE model is adopted to analyse the stability of the parasitic loop in the following discussions. According to equations (1) and (2), Kv=J/Ta. Then, the stability region can be expressed as

The stability region for Ta when β=3 and M=J/Kvi is shown in Fig. 8. It can be seen from Fig. 8 that the greater the αKx then the smaller the Ta; the greater the friction coefficient Kvi or the smaller the gimbal inertial moment J then the smaller the Ta. A smaller Ta means that the seeker’s angular rate tracking loop should be designed to respond more quickly.

caption.p: Stability region for Ta(β=3)

sec.p: The stability region for Ta when β=1 is given in Fig. 9. From this figure it is clear that if the response of the missile’s autopilot becomes faster then the stability region becomes smaller, and as a consequence the response speed of the seeker’s angular tracking control loop needs to be designed to be more rapid. This makes the design of the seeker’s control system more difficult and additional noise terms may be introduced into the seeker’s tracking loop.

caption.p: Stability region for Ta(β=1)

sec.title: 3.3 Example
sec.p: Using equation (1) and the data for a SSHS taken from reference [13] and reported in the Appendix, it can be calculated that K=125 and Tm=0.3675. Then, equation (5) reveals that a Ta value of less than 1/39 is approximately required to ensure the stability of the parasitic loop.

The Bode diagram for the DRE at Ta=1/45 (the corresponding controller parameters are Kv=0.1323 and Tv=0.3675) is shown in Fig. 10. The step-response of the parasitic loop is shown in Fig. 11, and from this figure it is clear that the parasitic loop is close to being unstable.

caption.p: Bode diagram for the DRE model (Ta=1/45)
Step-response of the parasitic loop (Ta=1/45)

sec.p: The Bode diagram for the DRE at Ta=1/300 (the response speed of the seeker’s angular rate tracking loop is faster than the previous case) is shown in Fig. 12 and the corresponding step-response of parasitic loop is shown in Fig. 13. It can be seen from these figures that the magnitude of the DRE decreases and the stability of the parasitic loop dramatically improves.

caption.p: Bode diagram for the DRE model (Ta=1/300)
Step-response of the parasitic loop (Ta=1/300)

sec.title: 4 Influence of the Counter EMF Coefficient on the Stability of the Parasitic Loop
4.1 Stability analysis
sec.p: The transfer function of the simplified DRE model obtained by only considering the counter EMF coefficient as the disturbance factor can be obtained from Fig. 3 as follows
since LTmTa/R and LTaKvi/(RKvi+KeKr) are very small, the transfer function of the DRE model can be simplified to

It can be inferred from equation (6) that the magnitude of GR(s) reaches its maximum near the frequency w=1/(TmTa) and its MM is about 20lg{1/[1+JR/(KrTaKe)]}. The relationship between counter EMF coefficient and the MM of the DRE model is shown in Fig. 14, where Q=JR/(KrTa). It can be seen from Fig. 14 that the greater the counter EMF coefficient Ke then the greater will be the MM of the DRE. The greater the Ta then the greater will be the MM of the DRE. The parasitic loop will become unstable when the MM of the DRE becomes large.

caption.p: The MM of the DRE model as a function of the counter EMF coefficient

sec.p: Similarly, the closed-loop transfer function of the parasitic loop in the dashed block of Fig. 4 can be obtained; the condition which ensures the stability of the parasitic loop can be approximated using Routh’s criterion as being
since Kv=Tm/(KTa), equation (7) can be simplified to

The stability region of Ta at β=3 and T=0.05, is shown in Fig. 15 and it is clear from this figure that the greater the αKx then the smaller will be the Ta; the greater the counter EMF coefficient Ke then the smaller will be Tm and in turn the smaller will be Ta, that is, the seeker’s inner angular rate tracking loop should be designed to respond quickly.

caption.p: Stability region for Ta(β=3)

sec.p: The stability region for Ta at β=1 and T=0.05 is shown in Fig. 16; from this figure it is clear that when the response of the autopilot becomes more rapid, the stability region becomes narrower, which makes the design of the seeker’s control system more difficult and additional noise terms may be introduced into the seeker’s tracking loop.

caption.p: Stability region for Ta(β=1)

sec.title: 4.2 Example
sec.p: Using the data for a SSHS taken from reference [13] and reported in the Appendix, equation (1) reveals that a Ta value of less than 1/150 is approximately required to ensure the stability of the parasiticloop.

The Bode diagram for the DRE at Ta=1/175 (the corresponding controller parameters are Kv=6.75 and Tv=0.0567) is shown in Fig. 17. The step-response of the parasitic loop is shown in Fig. 18, and from this figure it is clear that the parasitic loop is close to being unstable.

caption.p: Bode diagram for the DRE model (Ta=1/175)
Step-response of the parasitic loop (Ta=1/175)

sec.p: The Bode diagram for the DRE at Ta=1/300 (the response speed of the seeker’s angular rate tracking loop is faster than the previous case) is shown in Fig. 19 and the corresponding step-response of parasitic loop is shown in Fig. 20. It can be seen from these figures that the magnitude of the DRE decreases and the stability of the parasitic loop dramatically improves. If an improved step-response of the parasitic loop is required then the seeker’s angular rate tracking loop should be designed to response more rapidly.

caption.p: Bode diagram for the DRE (Ta=1/300)
Step-response of the parasitic loop (Ta=1/300)

sec.title: 5 Influence of Sensor Dynamics on the Parasitic Loop Stability
5.1 Stability analysis
sec.p: If only the dynamic characteristic of the sensors are considered then the required angular rate tracking control system is as shown in Fig. 21.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the angular rate tracking loop for the seeker

sec.p: Since the inertial time-constant of the angular sensor is very small, then the transfer function of the DRE model can be simplified to
The condition to ensure the stability of the parasitic loop can be approximated using Routh’s criterion as

Generally speaking, Tλ is so small that it can be ignored. The stability region of the inertial time-constant of the rate gyro when β=3 is shown in Fig. 22. From this figure it is clear that, the greater the αKx then the better will be the dynamics of the rate gyro; the smaller the T (the response speed of the seeker’s tracking control system becomes faster) then the better will be the dynamics of the rate gyro. The stability region of Tg at β=1 is shown in Fig. 23; it is clear from this figure that a rate gyro with better dynamics is needed when the response of the autopilot becomes faster.

caption.p: Stability region for Tg (β=3)
Stability region for Tg(β=1)

sec.title: 5.2 Example
sec.p: Using the data for a SSHS taken from reference [13] and reported in the Appendix, equation (9) reveals that a Ta value of less than 1/366 is approximately required to ensure the stability of the parasitic loop.

The Bode diagram for the DRE at Tg=1/380 is shown in Fig. 24. The step-response of the parasitic loop is shown in Fig. 25, and from this figure it is clear that the parasitic loop is close to being unstable. However, a rate gyro with better dynamics or a matching filter can be adopted to improve the stability of the parasitic loop [4].

caption.p: Bode diagram for the DRE (Tg=1/380)
Step-response of the parasitic loop (Tg=1/380)

sec.p: Assuming a rate gyro with better dynamics is applied, for example, let Tg=1/1500, then the Bode diagram for the DRE model becomes that shown in Fig. 26, and the corresponding step-response of the parasitic loop is shown in Fig. 27. From these figures it is clear that the magnitude of the DRE declines and the stability of the parasitic loop dramatically improves.

caption.p: Bode diagram for the DRE (Tg=1/1500)
Step-response of the parasitic loop (Tg=1/1500)

sec.p: When a matching filter is used to reduce the instability of the parasitic loop, the inertial time-constant of the matching filter is required to be less than that of the rate gyro [4], that is Tma≤Tg. Let Tg=1/380 and Tma=1/400, then the Bode diagram for the DRE model becomes that shown in Fig. 28, and the corresponding step-response of the parasitic loop is shown in Fig. 29. From these figures it is clear that the stability of parasitical loop is dramatically improved by the addition of a matching filter.

caption.p: Bode diagram for the DRE when a matching filter is used
Step-response of the parasitic loop when a matching filter is used

sec.title: 6 Simulation of the Composite System
sec.p: When all three disturbance factors i.e. the friction coefficient, counter EMF coefficient, and dynamic mismatches between the sensors, are considered together, the transfer function of the DRE model can be written as

The three parts of the right-hand side of the equation represent the DRE models induced by the friction coefficient, counter EMF coefficient, and dynamic mismatches between the sensors, respectively, where

Using the data for a SSHS taken from reference [13] and reported in the Appendix, and letting Ta=1/300, Tg=1/500, Tma=1/520, then the Bode magnitudes of the DRE and the step-response of the parasitical loop without the matching filter are shown in Fig. 30 and Fig. 31, respectively, and the corresponding data for the case with the matching filter is shown in Fig. 32 and Fig. 33, respectively. In these figures lines 1, 2, 3, and 4 represent the DRE induced by the friction coefficient, counter EMF coefficient, sensor dynamics, and the sum of all the three effects, respectively. It is can be seen from these figures that, for the SSHS in the Appendix, the the dynamics of the rate gyro have the largest influence on the stability of the parasitic loop, followed by the counter EMF coefficient if there is no matching filter in the SSHS.

caption.p: Magnitude of the DRE without matching filter
Step-response of the parasitic loop without matching filter
Magnitude of the DRE with matching filters
Step-response of the parasitic loop with matching filter

sec.title: 7 Conclusions
sec.p: The stability of the parasitic loop induced by the DRE of a SSHS is studied in this paper. Mathematical models of the DRE of the SSHS and the parasitic loop induced by the DRE are established in terms of disturbance factors such as friction coefficient, counter EMF coefficient, and dynamic mismatch between the sensors. First, the seeker’s tracking controller is designed so as to have a simple structure and then the explicit relationships between the control parameters and the desired performance index is presented.

The stability of the parasitic loop is analysed using Routh’s criterion. The results of this analysis illustrate that the response speed of the seeker’s angular rate tracking loop needs to be improved in order to negate the influence of friction coefficient and counter EMF coefficient on the parasitic loop. If the dynamics of the rate gyro are slow then the DRE of the seeker acts so as to destroy the stability of the parasitic loop and the guidance loop. A rate gyro with faster dynamics is required if the response speed of the seeker’s tracking control system becomes faster. However, if a rate gyro with faster dynamics is not available, an appropriate matching filter can be used to reduce the magnitude of the DRE and improve the stability of the parasitic loop.
Future research work will focus on stability region analysis of the parasitic loop when the moment and power of the electromotor are limited, and the mathematical model of 2-DOF SSHS is considered.
